title: Question 19

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for a rapidly growing, painful nodule on the right dorsal hand that appeared 6 weeks ago. Medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Keratoacanthomas present as a pink nodule with a keratin-filled center (“volcaniform” appearance), are rapidly growing and frequently painful, and are considered a variant of squamous cell carcinoma.
The most likely diagnosis is keratoacanthoma (

), which typically presents as a pink nodule with a keratin-filled center, giving it a “volcaniform” appearance. Keratoacanthomas grow rapidly (within 4-6 weeks) and are frequently painful. They are considered by many to be a variant of squamous cell carcinoma. After rapid growth, some keratoacanthomas tend to involute. Because keratoacanthomas are difficult to differentiate from cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, they are often treated with surgical excision. For this patient with a lesion on the dorsal right hand, Mohs micrographic surgery would most likely be performed.

) is a precancerous lesion that can potentially develop into squamous cell carcinoma. It presents as a thin papule or plaque with scale that is often more easily felt than seen. This patient's rapidly evolving papule with a keratin-filled center is not compatible with actinic keratosis.

) is a malignant neoplasm arising from the basal layer of the epidermis. There are different histologic subtypes, including superficial, pigmented, sclerotic, and nodular, that result in varying clinical appearance. Nodular basal cell carcinoma is the most common type, classically appearing as pearly papules with rolled borders and arborizing telangiectasias. . However, basal cell carcinomas do not have the keratin-filled center and typically do not develop as rapidly as this patient's lesion.

There is a characteristic violaceous border with an overhanging epithelium around the central exudative ulcer, which is often described as a “wet ulcer.” This patient's keratin-filled papule is not compatible with the diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum.
